This is showing up in grenade jobs which makes sense when we're starting up on the new side, tracked_instances will be empty but there would be instances on the host:

http://logstash.openstack.org/#dashboard/file/logstash.json?query=message%3A%5C%22Re-fetching%20instances%5C%22%20AND%20tags%3A%5C%22screen-n-cpu.txt%5C%22&from=7d

So we should avoid this if startup is True.

What you've done here is probably more explicit, and since it does a break (below) we don't have to traverse the whole list if there is a mismatch, however, if we believe that the common case is that we _won't_ break, then we are doing a repeated 'instance.uuid in self.tracked_instances'.

We could instead

    instance_uuids = set([instance.uuid for instance in instances])
    # if the sets aren't concurrent load again
    set_diff = instance_uuids - self.tracked_instances
    if set_diff:
        if check vm_state of the set_diff:
            do the reload

or some such. May not be worth it, but I've become very conscious of the cost of big loops in nova-compute lately...

monitor-helm-elastic/files/0005-set-init.message: does host-lock controller-0 after a swact work ok with this change?  Kibana should still be accessible and indexing.

Yes.  The initial_master_nodes is just used to bootstrap the cluster.  Setting it just to master-0 means master-0 can elect itself as master without waiting for other masters to join when the master-0 pod is initially created.  After other nodes have joined, the cluster will use the discovered masters to elect a master, not just master-0.

Good reference for cluster bootstrap: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/modules-discovery-bootstrap-cluster.html

From the above:
"It is technically sufficient to set cluster.initial_master_nodes on a single master-eligible node in the cluster, and only to mention that single node in the setting’s value, but this provides no fault tolerance before the cluster has fully formed."

I think that is fine, as we don't really need fault tolerance before the cluster is formed on initial application-apply. We don't want to proceed unless the first master-0 pod comes up properly.

@Akihiro, there was an issue with fields mapping which was not supporting field with class type and that field was getting skipped. It's now corrected so no change is required here.
Parentheses don't create a tuple, the comma does. This change does nothing.
It works perfectly now. Earlier, It was skipping as we don't define classes as fields but by condition we can pass through class field to field mapping (_dynamic_properties).

From the readability, the following looks better:

   if (accessor_expr not in fields and
       not inspect.isclass(accessor_expr)):

My comment in patch set 5 [1] is not answered yet.

If accessor_expr is a class, more processing will be skipped by this patch. Then, what does L.356-358 mean? I think L.356-358 covers a case where a accesor_expr is a class.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/686018/3/openstack_dashboard/test/integration_tests/regions/forms.py@351

The aim of this condition is to skip fields which are not present in web form for backward compatibility. Lets say in Ocata, network field "az_hints" was not available so we can skip that field here and continue with other fields. I made it generic so if we don't have specified field, field mapping should work as usual. This condition doesn't skip if accessor_expr is a class. That is why members field which maps to a class works properly. It does map web fields and class type both.

if no stop condition and 'max' is set, it will stop after the max value AFAIK. So adjusting it to match our expectations.
My understanding is that max is the max number of seconds it will get to. It's an exponential backoff until value of max. then it uses the value of max.

My understanding based on the docs is that this will loop forever. Currently we want to wait forever. This has a possible side effect of never completing if something in the locking goes wrong. If you want to prevent that we could put an overall cap of like 60 minutes or something and then reraise.

container_config_scripts/pacemaker_resta.message:
shouldn't the colon be before the equal sign ?  
${parameter:=default} , i.e :

: ${TRIPLEO_MINOR_UPDATE=false} => ${TRIPLEO_MINOR_UPDATE:=false}

(as in https://www.tldp.org/LDP/abs/html/parameter-substitution.html)..

I just wanted to avoid a bash error, I'm actually not interested in solving the exact valuation of TRIPLEO_MINOR_UPDATE, since I'm only comparing it explicitly against value "true". So I'd say it's good enough for our need.

ack OK, but is there a reason, i.e. is '=' better than ':='

ack per irc just now its urgent

ack on that but Pini is also right, at least I've only ever seen that conditional assignment with ":" i.e.:

: ${TRIPLEO_MINOR_UPDATE:=false}

and it also solves the empty string case:

[m@192 ~]$ FOO="" ; bash -uc : ${FOO:=foo}; echo $FOO
foo
[m@192 ~]$ FOO="" ; bash -uc : ${FOO=foo}; echo $FOO

No I do that on purpose, this is a bash idiom that uses the ':' operation to ignore the output of this statement, but still execute run the variable assignment as a side effect.

Then I'm trying to avoid undefined variable only, because I run set -u. So I only want to assign a value if the variable has never been set before. So per your link above, I shall use ${parameter=default}

To summarize: I want to avoid this error:

    # bash -uc 'echo $FOO'    
    bash: FOO: unbound variable

So I'm setting a value to FOO:

    # bash -uc ': ${FOO=foo}; echo $FOO'
    foo

But only if FOO has no value already set:

    # FOO=bar bash -uc ': ${FOO=foo}; echo $FOO' 
    bar

And if FOO is empty, I don't care either, because that doesn't cause an error:

    # FOO= bash -uc ': ${FOO=foo}; echo $FOO'
IMHO TRIPLEO_MINOR_UPDATE="${TRIPLEO_MINOR_UPDATE:-false}" would make this much more readable. I had no idea what this syntax does (and clearly i'm not alone in this)

.pre-commit-config.yaml.message: The commit messages says 'master version'. Why are we lock to a hash revision?

pre-commit does not allow use of 'master' because it would not give predictable results. Only tags and revisions are
allowed. Because ansible-lint did not receive a tag yet, we point to the newer revision.

After they tag the new release, we will be able to auto update to it by running `pre-commit autoupdate` which looks for newest tags on all hooks.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Is this going to result in a change to the default OAM or Management addresses? Is it going to allow a user to allocate the gateway address to something else?

It is understood that the past convention is that the second address (.2) in the subnet was used as the floating address, however this is arbitrary.  In fact, since we use the floating address as the gateway for the other hosts, it actually makes more sense to have this as the .1 address, since that is typically the convention for gateways.

Other than straying from what we are accustomed to, there is no technical reason to start with .2 and a .1 address is more conventional.

In all cases, the deployment can be overridden with specific start and end addresses if the default behaviour is not desirable.

I will let Matt or Greg comment, but I don't think we should be using the .1 address because:
1. Convention is that the .1 address is reserved for a gateway.
2. Users are used to having .2 as the floating address and this will probably at least temporarily break user tools/workflows.
Will do.
So back to my question - will a user be able to allocate 192.168.0.1 to a host?

OK - thanks for explaining.

David - make sure you send a message to the mailing list when you push this so people aren't surprised by the change in behaviour.

This will only impact the mgmt, pxeboot and cluster host networks. 

Currently if a management subnet of 192.168.0.0/24 is specified, but no management_start_address is provided, a management_start_address of 192.168.0.2 is used. After this update the management_start_address would be 192.168.0.1

The rest of the behavior is unchanged.

kuryr_kubernetes/controller/handlers/nam.message: Can we just have clients.get_network_client() not to always do .network? It's how Octavia was implemented.

Is there a reason for this not being a Python dict anymore?
The items retrieval will fail in the next line.

The quota returned by the OpenStackSDK client has the following format: 

openstack.network.v2.quota.Quota(subnet=100, network=100, floatingip=50, subnetpool=-1, id=bcd9dea442274994b03ca150ab2441a4, security_group_rule=100, location=Munch({'project': Munch({'domain_id': None, 'id': u'e632637b422847a9ad24b73801841a6e', 'name': None, 'domain_name': None}), 'zone': None, 'region_name': None, 'cloud': '10.11.4.14'}),
 security_group=100, router=10, rbac_policy=10, port=500)

puppet/services/tripleo-packages.yaml.message: afaics and per the commit message this should be a copy/pasta of https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/src/commit/5ffad3a3f07d8f93e6930edb3ad3f7bd5345f23f/deployment/tripleo-packages/tripleo-packages-baremetal-puppet.yaml#L216 (except you skipped the last task for setting flag to skip - i guess as this is minor update only so we don't have to worry about the upgrade case here)

Yes. The flag run_ovs_update is skipped for minor update.

This flag "run_ovs_update" is required to update the openvswitch package, when there is a specific issue on ovs rpm (without the package name change to openvswitch2.11). IIRC, this specific issue on the ovs rpm was present in ovs2.5.0-14 and lesser versions. The issue is that, when openvswitch package is updated to a new version, it restarts the ovs service (ovs2.5.0-14 to ovs2.6 will restart the ovs service).

It has been fixed in the later versions and also in ovs2.6 and ovs2.9 version. So in the later versions, if the openvswitch pacakge is updated (for example, ovs2.6 to ovs2.9), the ovs service will NOT be restarted. 

The flag "run_ovs_update" is required for this specific issue for ovs2.5.0-14 or lesser versions. For queens, we are always on ovs2.9, so we will never hit this issue. The flag is not required, and I removed it.

sanity check... and we don't need the cases of checking if this is not 'layered package' ... i.e. it will never be something less than 2.11 here? thinking about that bit https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/src/commit/5ffad3a3f07d8f93e6930edb3ad3f7bd5345f23f/deployment/tripleo-packages/tripleo-packages-baremetal-puppet.yaml#L276

If it is layered product, it will be handled with earlier block. If it is NOT layered product (ovs2.9.0-x to ovs2.9.0-y), then "Update all packages" step below, will handle the openvswitch package update too and the ovs service will not be restarted (as ovs rpm will not trigger the scripts during update).

Ok, let me play out a scenario so that I understand it better.
We have 3 Routers, R1, R2 and R3, and 2 Chassis, C1 and C2.
We have R1 and R2 are master on C1 and R3 is master on C2.
When we add the new chassis C3, all three routers should be scheduled on C3, with the lowest priority, isnt it?
And right, we should not move R1 and R2 to C2/C3, since C1 is the Master for R1 and R2.

Ok, so I have created a table of sorts, I would like everyone's opinion on it, that is the way I am planning to rebalance. I know it requires continuous movement of routers whenever a new chassis is added, contributing to downtime which conflicts with one of the above points, but without rebalancing, the whole structure looks weak/solely dependent on some chassis.

After IRC discussion with ajo, please forget the 'schema' part. The reference won't go away for very good reasons: if one controller is rebooted, the gw port remains scheduled on it, otherwise it'll be lost.

Miguel's point is very good, let's take into account where the port is actually bound to instead of relying just on the priorities.

Let me extend your scenario with a more extreme example:

* 100 routers. C1 and C2 (let's say that C1 hosts 50 masters and C2 the other 50)
* You add 3 more chassis (C3, C4, C5).
* Based on your comment, when C3 is added, all 100 routers will be scheduled with lowest prio there. The same goes for C4 and C5. This means that C3 will have all the routers with the same priority. The same goes for C4 and C5.
* Now C1 and C2 goes down.
* You end up having all 100 routers being master on C3.

Ideally, what you should have is 33 on C3, 33 on C4 and 33 on C5 (the remaining one, wherever it falls :) for the LeastLoaded scheduler. For the Chance, you can't guarantee it but I wouldn't expect to have 100% 0% 0% with a 'big' number of gateway ports.

As for minimizing the downtime, this document should cover the approach taken. Some possibilities could be:

- *not move* the master gateway ports at all (As Miguel wisely pointed out, master gateway ports at any given moment are not necessarily highest priority ones)
- do it only when the unbalance ratio is above a threshold (not configurable I'd say): for example, if there's more than N gateway ports on a chassis and the cloud unbalance factor is >75%, then let's move masters around.   N and 75% are arbitrary, we can define whatever in this document and later in your implementation come up with concrete values based on your testing, failover times, feedback, ...

I'm not going to spam a comment to all the proposed changes in this set, but I expect it applies to all of them. The routine which parses the expires-in field can be found here:

https://opendev.org/openstack/election/src/commit/cf67b3f156cecca0c84109c819bf7eaf77214959/openstack_election/utils.py#L216-L221

It currently expects a month and year so that it can check whether the listing expires before the election (technically before the end date for the eligibility timeframe), so more like...

    expires-in: July 2020

If you can work out a programmatic means of parsing other sorts of syntax to achieve the desired result, I'm happy to review patches to that module implementing it.

Digging deeper, the check_atc_date() function is only called from check_candidacy.py (which you still might eventually be interested in using, for example from a Zuul job like OpenStack's election officials do). It's not going to cause a problem with the current state of electoral roll generation, but in reality that function probably *should* also be applied to filter invalid (expired extra-atc) voters from the rolls, it's just not used for that yet.

We have a rough estimate on elections however are planning to stick a cadence now. In that sense I think setting it a month would be better as that also encourages us to keep a timeline. I'll switch to 'November' from 'H2'.
Shoot, sorry, fixed it here now. :/

doc/source/installation.rst.message:
cinderlib doesn't use the taskflow for volume creation?

https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/cinder/volume/flows/manager/create_volume.py

OMG!!  What a mistake!!
Thanks for catching this.  :-)
No, because cinderlib's volume creation is simple compared to Cinder's.  No scheduling, no retrying, no create from image...
Oh, this reminds me - some drivers actually use taskflow internally. So even if the create_volume flow is only via the manager, we probably still need it for some drivers.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Please, follow https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages

- You should add a one-line title: the title could be something like:
"Add test to create and update valid DSCP values"

- Leave an empty line
- Make a description
- If possible, add a bug reference

neutron_tempest_plugin/api/base.py.message: Note, setting this here can affect other tests and cause them to fail in case they don't have os_admin attribute

Hi Noy,
This change can affect other tests because you are changing class that many other classes use as a base. In case some of them do not have os_admin attribute they will fail. This can be seen in the logs of failed CI jobs e.g.
https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/09df4bede0c24c21857221dee46145bf that you can find on the gerrit page.
I think it could be safer to extend setup_clients in QosTest class.

Hi Roman!
Can you please explain why it could affect other tests?
I added this additional client because creating\deleting QoS policies in the cleanup stage requires admin_client.

Thanks a lot Roman!
I will fix it
You had a comment on this before
Have a feeling that this is causing your issue in the CI.
Why You need to remove it from here?
I definitely should not remove it, my mistake.

neutron_tempest_plugin/api/test_qos.py.message:
Since the list is finite, rather than going through this logic it would be a lot easier - and readable - to just use an array of the valid marks like I did here [1]. 

https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lib/src/branch/master/neutron_lib/constants.py#L335-L336
I don't see these in the other tests for DSCP, is this handled by the parent class?

If the resources are specific to the test then sure, clean up in the test.
If the resources are generally used in the test class, like multiple tests create a qos policy or a network, then it should be done in tearDown. It's always good to try to avoid code duplication.

I though that it's a good practice to add those cleanups in order to make sure that the test will remove any of resources used during the test 
(without being dependent on the teardown stage).
Should I remove it?
I'm not sure should this just be it's own test rather than a function in another test.
neutron_lib.constants.VALID_DSCP_MARKS is an ordered list, you can use first element then
I would name it as n_constants or just constants as there is already loaded module qos_const and this may be confusing
You don't need to add this cleanup. If You are using self.create_network() it will automatically clean it after test will be done.

Got it, Thank you.
I thought it could be good practice to add it anyway, however I'v noticed David's explanation about it.
0 was actually set above, so here You are testing setting marks from 8
Not must, but maybe it would be better to move this method definition to the top of "test_qos_dscp_create_and_update", for example into line 1000 before "# Setup network".
I would suggest to use third parameter in assertion method, which is "msg". Make sure to include "failed dscp_mark" in it, in order to provide detailed error in case of test failure.
nitty nit: single " is enough here :)

neutron_tempest_plugin/scenario/test_qos.message:
I think that we should also check odd numbers (shouldn't be supported), therefore "step 2" in "xrange" is not really needed.
It will increase the execution time a bit (to run ~*2 API requests), but it's not critical.

The test was moved from scenario/test_qos to api/test_qos.
In addition, the mentioned issues was fixed :)

It's clear to me why MAX is set to 58, but it may confuse a bit, because in feature requirements the last supported value is 56.
So I would suggest to change the MAX parameter to be 56 and then to modify _update_dscp_mark_values by +1, it means:

for mark in range(self.MIN_VALID_DSCP_MARK, self.MAX_VALID_DSCP_MARK+1)

So 56 will also be included and tested.
this all is more API test instead of scenario one.

this whole test is API test, not scenario one. Please move it somewhere to api tests module.

In scenario test You should do e.g. something like:
1. Create qos policy with DSCP marking rule,
2. Spawn 2 VMs,
3. Assign this policy to port which is used by one of VMs (src vm),
4. Run e.g. tcpdump on dest vm,
5. Send traffic from src vm to dest vm and check on dest vm that packets were sent with proper DSCP mark. 

Quite similar test is already done in fullstack tests: https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/tests/fullstack/test_qos.py#L475
this line is too long I guess
Should this line have been deleted?

Add a line here too.
Though this is just a nit.
This line can stay, it probably should have been there from the start.

Hi,
I added this manually because I'v notice that the policy variable that is created in this function is not being deleted in the end of the test (because it was never being inserted into the 'qos_policies' list.)
However, I removed that in the current version.

Hi Marios!!! Thanks for the feedback, I have the steps defined here: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/687479/23/zuul.d/layout.yaml

@Carlos consider coming to the community call today half hour before the tripleo weekly @ meet.google.com/bqx-xwht-wky

we can see what the others think and if there are better suggestions about it

ah I see.. i think then you probably need required-projects so it will checkout the tht into the job directory see https://zuul-ci.org/docs/zuul/user/config.html#attr-job.required-projects

you can find lots of examples of that in the ci jobs  https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ci/src/branch/master/zuul.d/base.yaml#L28

but -1 on having the job definition like that and then overriding it in the layout of another project to run the actual job playbooks.

even if required-projects doesn't solve the problem then we'll find some other solution but i don't think we should do that
